Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Cooperative Work

title.narrative: Department of Inspection for Livestock Inputs, Brazil Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Food Supply

description.narrative: On December 7-8, the CVB hosted Mr. Ricardo Pamplona, Director, and Maralice Cotta, Technical Assistant, of the Department of Inspection for Livestock Inputs, Brazil Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Food Supply. Mr. Pamplona and Ms. Cotta are updating the Brazilian biological safety standards and will be visiting the USDA animal areas in Ames, Iowa, to exchange technical information with colleagues from the CVB and others at the National Centers for Animal Health (NCAH)

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: Workshop

description.narrative: Workshop held in Brazil to present the application of Incident Command System (ICS) elements in response to animal disease outbreaks to an audience of Veterinary Services of South American countries. Representatives from Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Guyana, Paraguay, Peru, and Surinam participated. The activity included a poultry disease outbreak response exercise. University of Delaware staff participated in the training. The training enhanced the capability of regional professionals to coordinate a response to animal disease outbreaks applying the principals of the ICS.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Emergency Poultry Disease Response Course

description.narrative: From June 20-24, 2016, The Emergency Poultry Disease Response Course (EPDR) was funded by USDA APHIS and implemented by the University of Delaware (UD) Avian Biosciences Center (ABC), a part of the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: Workshop on Methodologies for the Assessment of Surveillance Systems Components for FMD and other Transboundary Animal Diseases - Implementation of the technical working guide for the last phase of PHEFA

description.narrative: From September 26-30, 2016, the Assessment of Surveillance Systems Components for FMD and TAD Workshop was held in Brazil. Under the agreement for international cooperation with PANAFTOSA, USDA-APHIS supported the implementation of an international workshop entitled "Methodologies for the Assessment of Surveillance Systems Components for FMD and other Transboundary Animal Diseases".

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: Irradiation as a Quarantine Treatment Seminar

description.narrative: The Brazilian National Plant Protection Organization (MAPA-DSV) proposed the organization of a SEMINAR to discuss the use of irradiation as a quarantine treatment to facilitate the trade of fresh fruits with United States. Brazil produces and exports tropical fruits to different markets in the Americas, Europe and Asia, but faces a significant limitation on their exports to United States due to phytosanitary restriction that could be addressed with the use of irradiation as a quarantine treatment. MAPA-DSV has regulated the use of irradiation in Brazil, but producers and exporters still present resistance to use this technology, mostly due to misconception about its risk and acceptance by the U.S. consumers. An APHIS official provided a presentation on the U.S. regulatory framework to allow the use of irradiation as a quarantine treatment in United States.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Agricultural Quarantine Inspection User Fee Account
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Agricultural Quarantine Inspection User Fee Account

title.narrative: Organization, Production and Distribution of Inter-Laboratory Comparison Tests

description.narrative: USDA-APHIS supported the establishment of the South American Network of Avian Influenza and Newcastle Disease Diagnostic Laboratories - RESUDIA - in 2014 to strengthen the capacity of reference laboratories to diagnose avian influenza and the disease of Newcastle in the region. OIE designated a RESUDIA laboratory as a reference laboratory for avian influenze and Newcastle disease in May 2016, a significant accomplishment. Through this current project, APHIS will assist RESUDIA with it's next priority, the definition of mechanisms for production and distribution of reference materials and proficiency testing or interlaboratory tests within RESUDIA.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: Identification and Management of Citrus Greening Disease Workshop

description.narrative: Citrus greening disease affects trade of fresh citrus fruits. It is present on some countries in the Americas, including the United States, and heavily regulated by those countries that have not reported the disease yet. The objective of this event was to provide participants with the latest strategies for the identification, response and control of citrus greening disease. This workshop proposed an exchange of information between plant health specialist of countries that have reported the disease and countries that have not reported the disease. The participants discussed proper mitigation strategies to reduce the risk of greening on fresh citrus fruits and learn about management and control measures that have been working in countries affected by the disease.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Agricultural Quarantine Inspection User Fee Account
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Agricultural Quarantine Inspection User Fee Account

title.narrative: Risk Based Sampling Workshop

description.narrative: APHIS and other foriegn national plant protection organizations are developing a data-driven strategy to maximize the effectiveness of port inspections. The goal of this strategy is to prioritize inspection activities based on risk and detecting a consistent level of infestations. This strategy takes into consideration pest interception data and rates to determine statistically based sampling protocols. APHIS is providing training on these methods to assist counterparts from Brazil in enhancing their inspection activities based on risk as well as expedite the clearance of agricultural commodities.

title.narrative: Agricultural Research Basic and Applied Research

description.narrative: DETECTION AND CHARACTERIZATION OF POTENTIAL EMERGING ARBOVIRUSES IN BRAZIL - THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO DEVELOP AND/OR APPLY NEW ARS TECHNOLOGY TO DETECT AND CHARACTERIZE ARBOVIRUSES PRESENT IN BRAZIL THAT COULD POSE EMERGING ANIMAL DISEASE THREATS AND DEVELOP A BASELINE OF VIRUS POPULATI

title.narrative: AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH

description.narrative: DETECTION AND CHARACTERIZATION OF POTENTIAL EMERGING ARBOVIRUSES IN BRAZIL - THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO DEVELOP AND/OR APPLY NEW ARS TECHNOLOGY TO DETECT AND CHARACTERIZE ARBOVIRUSES PRESENT IN BRAZIL THAT COULD POSE EMERGING ANIMAL DISEASE THREATS AND DEVELOP A BASELINE OF VIRUS POPULATION VARIABILITY. THE AREA TO BE INVESTIGATED WILL INCLUDE BOUNDARY AREAS BETWEEN RURAL AND SYLVATIC HABITATS THAT WILL INFORM PREDICTIVE MODELS OF EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, DEFORESTATION AND LIVESTOCK ENCROACHMENT INTO WILD AREAS EFFECTS ON POTENT EMERGENCE OF ARBOVIRUSES.

title.narrative: Agricultural Research Basic and Applied Research

description.narrative: EVOLUTION OF INFLUENZA A VIRUS IN SWINE IN BRAZIL - THE GOAL OF THIS COLLABORATION PROPOSAL IS TO USE ADVANCED PHYLOGENETIC ANALYSES, PROTEIN MODELING, AND ANTIGENIC CARTOGRAPHY RESOURCES TO FURTHER CHARACTERIZE IAV FROM SWINE IN BRAZIL.

title.narrative: Scientific Exchange Program

description.narrative: The Scientific Exchange Program (SEP) advances USDAs agricultural research goals to promote collaborative programs among agricultural professionals of eligible countries, the United States, the international agricultural research system, and United States entities conducting research in the agricultural sciences.

title.narrative: Scientific Cooperation Research Program - Nutrient Management Fertilizer

description.narrative: The Scientific Cooperation Research Program supports joint research, extension, and education projects lasting up to two years among domestic and international agricultural professionals. These projects address issues including agricultural trade and market access, animal and plant health, biotechnology, food safety and security, and sustainable natural resource management.
